questions.text: Enzyme activated by a decrease in insulin: glucagon ratio is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Glucose 6-phosphatase

 

Glucose 6-phosphatase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of glucose-6-phosphate back to glucose. It is activated when the insulin-to-glucagon ratio decreases. This enzyme plays a crucial role in gluconeogenesis, the process of synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources when blood glucose levels are low.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucokinase: Glucokinase is an enzyme that phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It is primarily found in the liver and pancreatic beta cells. Glucokinase's activity is influenced by glucose levels, not the insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

 

Option B. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is another enzyme that phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. It is present in various tissues, but its activity is not directly regulated by changes in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio's

 

Option C. Phosphofructokinase (PFK): Phosphofructokinase is an enzyme involved in glycolysis, the metabolic pathway that converts glucose to pyruvate. It plays a role in glucose metabolism but is not activated by a decrease in the insulin-to-glucagon ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Low insulin glucagon ratio means it is fasting state, as in fed state insulin is more. So in fasting state glucose-6-phosphatase will be active as this enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis, which occurs during fasting.
  • Phosphofructokinase is involved in glycolysis. PFK-1 is active in any situation and PFK-2 is active only in fed state.
  • Glucokinase phosphorylates glucose in liver and pancreas, active in fed state and is induced by insulin.
  • Hexokinase also phosphorylates glucose and is present in all cells of the body. It is active in any situation in body as it is a general enzyme to phosphorylate glucose.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 137-138

questions.text: An elderly man presents with rigidity and tremors. On examination, he has blank facial expressions. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selegiline

 

The patient's symptoms of rigidity, tremors, and blank facial expressions are suggestive of Parkinson's disease, a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor that is used in the management of Parkinson's disease. It works by inhibiting the breakdown of dopamine, thereby increasing its availability in the brain and helping to alleviate symptoms like rigidity and tremors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clozapine: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic primarily used in the treatment of schizophrenia. While it can be used in Parkinson's disease patients who experience psychosis, it is not a first-line treatment for the primary motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

 

Option B. Donepezil: Donepezil is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of Alzheimer’s disease. It enhances cholinergic function by increasing the concentration of acetylcholine in the brain. It is not typically used for treating Parkinson's disease.

 

Option D. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic and can actually worsen Parkinson's disease symptoms. It blocks dopamine receptors, which could exacerbate the dopamine deficiency characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor that increases dopamine availability in the brain and is used to manage the motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease, such as rigidity and tremors.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes this?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Niacin

 

This is Casal’s necklace shown in picture, which occurs in Vitamin B3/ Niacin deficiency. Niacin can be formed in the body from amino acid tryptophan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Thiamine is an essential B-vitamin that plays a crucial role in energy metabolism. It helps the body convert food (carbohydrates) into energy (ATP). Thiamine is important for the proper functioning of nerves and muscles. Deficiency can lead to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which affect the nervous system.

 

Option C. Zinc: Zinc is a trace mineral that is crucial for the immune system, wound healing, and DNA synthesis. It also plays a role in maintaining a sense of taste and smell. Zinc deficiency can lead to impaired immune function, delayed wound healing, and other health issues. It is an essential nutrient for overall health.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine is another B-vitamin that is involved in various metabolic processes, including amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis. It plays a role in maintaining brain health and proper nerve function. Pyridoxine deficiency can lead to symptoms like anemia, nerve damage, and skin issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin is another B-vitamin that is essential for various bodily functions. It plays a role in converting nutrients into energy, creating cholesterol and fats, repairing DNA, and acting as an antioxidant. Niacin is important for overall metabolic health. Severe niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which can have serious effects on the skin, digestive system, and nervous system.

 

Niacin deficiency can be caused by:

  • Dietary deficiency of tryptophan
  • Dietary deficiency Vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency
  • Carcinoid syndrome
  • Hartnup’s disease

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text: The temperature of a body of a deceased person is found to be 39 degrees Celsius. Which of the following is the most probable reason? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Septicaemia

 

Septicaemia, a severe infection where bacteria enter the bloodstream, causes the body to produce a high fever due to excessive bacterial activity. This can result in postmortem caloricity, where the body temperature remains elevated after death.

 

Postmortem Caloricity: Usually cooling of the body occurs after death, however in certain exceptional conditions the body temperatures remain increased after death for 2-3 hours. This is called Postmortem Caloricity.

 

It can Occur due to two reasons:

 

1) Body temperature was too high before death

 

  1. When Heat regulation is disturbed before death: Heat Stroke, pontine hemorrhage    
  2. Increased heat production due to convulsions: Strychnine poisoning and tetanus
  3. Increased heat production due to excessive bacterial activity: Infectious diseases (Septicaemia, typhoid etc.)

 

2) Very high environmental temperature

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyanide poisoning: Cyanide poisoning leads to rapid death by inhibiting cellular respiration, but it does not typically cause elevated postmortem body temperature.

 

Option C. Corrosive poisoning: Corrosive poisons cause tissue damage and may lead to symptoms such as pain and vomiting, but they do not typically result in postmortem caloricity.

 

Option D. Intra-abdominal hemorrhage: Intra-abdominal hemorrhage involves bleeding within the abdominal cavity, which does not cause elevated postmortem body temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Postmortem caloricity, where the body temperature remains elevated after death, can occur due to high body temperature before death, such as in cases of septicaemia, heat stroke, and certain poisonings, or due to very high environmental temperature.

 

Ref: Textbook of forensic medicine and toxicology, 5th edition, Krishan Vij, page 81

questions.text: A female presented with a long history of fever, discolored skin of lower limbs, and lower limb edema. Microscopic examination showed a sheathed organism with no nuclei at the tip of the tail. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wuchereria bancrofti

 

Wuchereria bancrofti is a filarial worm responsible for lymphatic filariasis, which often presents with symptoms such as prolonged fever, discolored skin, and limb edema due to lymphatic blockage. Microscopic examination of the organism reveals a sheathed microfilaria with no nuclei at the tip of the tail, which is characteristic of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mansonella: Mansonella species are generally unsheathed microfilariae and do not match the description of having no nuclei at the tail tip, making this an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Loa loa: Loa loa, also known as the African eye worm, is a sheathed microfilaria that has continuous nuclei to the very end of the tail, which distinguishes it from Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Option D. Brugia malayi: Brugia malayi is another sheathed filarial worm but is characterized by having nuclei at the tail tip, typically in two distinct spots, unlike Wuchereria bancrofti, which has none.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with symptoms of lymphatic filariasis and a sheathed microfilaria with no tail tip nuclei, Wuchereria bancrofti is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

From the given clinical features, the most likely disease is visceral leishmaniasis or Kala azar caused by Leishmania donovani, and the vector is sandfly. A patient from Uttar Pradesh presenting with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly with a smear examination showing pancytopenia and macrophages containing organisms with kinetoplasts point towards the diagnosis.

 

 

Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

 

  • Amastigote form (also called LD bodies)- It is seen within macrophages and contains a kinetoplast.
  • Promastigote form- It is the infective form in the sandfly. The kinetoplast is seen at the anterior end.

 

Kinetoplast are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to nucleus. They consist of blepharoplast and parabasal body. Flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

 

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: Transmits trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Triatomine bug: Known for spreading Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

questions.text: Viral infection causing transient aplastic anemia is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B-19

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 infection targets erythroid cell lines, particularly the pronormoblast stage, and is known to cause transient aplastic anemia, particularly in patients with underlying hemolytic disorders, as well as other clinical manifestations such as erythema infectiosum, arthritis, and non-immune fetal hydrops.

questions.text: What is the site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Optic tract

 

The site of lesion in Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is optic tract.

 

Wernicke hemianopic pupil is a type of light reflex. The blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction on illumination, while the normal side of the retina shows a pupillary reaction.

 

It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract. It is also seen in cases such as TB, syphilis and tumors of the optic thalamus.

 

Homonymous hemianopia HH is characteristically seen in optic tract pathway

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve: Incorrect. A lesion in the optic nerve typically results in a loss of vision in the eye served by the affected nerve but does not produce hemianopic pupillary responses. Instead, it might lead to a direct pupillary defect (also known as a relative afferent pupillary defect or Marcus Gunn pupil).

 

Option C. Optic radiation: Incorrect. Lesions in the optic radiation cause visual field deficits (typically homonymous hemianopia) but do not affect the pupillary light reflex because the optic radiations carry visual information from the thalamus to the visual cortex and are not involved in the reflex arc of the pupil light reflex.

 

Option D. Optic chiasma: Incorrect. Lesions at the optic chiasm typically cause bitemporal hemianopia due to the crossing of nasal retinal fibers at this location. This type of lesion affects the visual fields of both eyes but does not specifically result in a hemianopic pupillary response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lesion site for Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is the optic tract, which when damaged, leads to a characteristic pupillary response where the pupil does not react to light shown on the side of the retina corresponding to the damaged tract. This finding is indicative of a post-chiasmal visual pathway issue and is useful for localizing neurological damage in clinical assessments.

questions.text: A patient with deep vein thrombosis was started on a new drug. After 2 days, he presented with the given finding. Which of the following drugs is implicated in causing the below condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Warfarin

 

The figure shows clinical picture of dermal vascular necrosis, also known as ‘purple toe syndrome’. It is an early adverse effect of warfarin. It is seen in patients with genetic protein C deficiency.

 

Dermal Vascular Necrosis

 

  • Warfarin-induced dermal vascular necrosis is a rare complication of warfarin therapy.
  • It characterized by the development of painful skin lesions in patients taking warfarin.
  • It is thought to be caused by a transient hypercoagulable state resulting from a rapid reduction in protein C levels in patients with underlying protein C deficiency or other risk factors.
  • The lesions typically occur in areas with a high concentration of adipose tissue, such as the breasts, thighs, and buttocks.
  • The initial symptoms include red or purple spots on the skin that can quickly progress to painful, necrotic lesions with a central blister or eschar.
  • The diagnosis is usually made clinically based on the characteristic appearance of the lesions and the patient's history of warfarin therapy.
  • The treatment of dermal vascular necrosis involves stopping warfarin and initiating alternative anticoagulant therapy, such as heparin or low molecular weight heparin.
  • In severe cases, surgical intervention may be necessary to remove the necrotic tissue and prevent further damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that works by activating antithrombin III, which in turn inhibits thrombin and factor Xa. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis. However, heparin can cause other complications such as heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

 

Option C. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor used as an anticoagulant. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis and is generally associated with a different profile of side effects, including bleeding.

 

Option D. Rivaroxaban: Rivaroxaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor used for anticoagulation. It does not cause dermal vascular necrosis and is associated with a different side effect profile, mainly related to bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin can cause dermal vascular necrosis, particularly in patients with protein C deficiency, presenting as painful, necrotic skin lesions shortly after initiation of therapy.

choices.text: Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the pituitary
Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus
Hyperthyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with complaints of lethargy, increased sleep, and weight gain. Investigations revealed low plasma TSH concentration. However, on the administration of TRH, the TSH levels increased. Which of the following conditions is likely in this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hypothyroidism due to disease in the hypothalamus

 

Clinical history is suggestive of hypothyroidism. Presence of low TSH with suspected hypothyroidism indicates loss of Log relationship of TSH & fT4 indicating a central cause. Administration of TRH improving TSH level indicates TRH deficiency which is mainly produced from the hypothalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Hyperthyroidism due to pituitary:  Cause like TSHoma is very rare. Also, symptoms of thyrotoxicosis are not present in the patient.

 

Option B. In pituitary disease: TSH will not improve with TRH administration as the gland is defective and cannot produce TSH.

 

Option D. Thyrotoxicosis symptoms are not present in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When evaluating a patient with hypothyroid symptoms and low TSH that responds to TRH administration, consider hypothalamic dysfunction as a probable cause. This is indicative of secondary hypothyroidism due to a lack of TRH production, affecting the pituitary’s secretion of TSH in the absence of exogenous stimulation.

 

Reference - Harrison/Hypothyroidism/Chap 383

choices.text: Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar
Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies
It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever, multiple seizures, headache, and neck rigidity. CSF analysis showed low glucose, high protein, and many polymorphs. The CSF culture showed pleomorphic gram-negative bacilli. What is true about the causative organism? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus colonies

 

The patient with given complaints points to meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae and it exhibits satellitism around Staphylococcus colonies. When present in the sputum, H. influenzae appears as a coccobacillus, but in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), it appears as a filamentous bacillus.

 

H. influenzae can grow on blood agar if the source of V factor is provided

 

When S. aureus is streaked across a blood agar plate perpendicular to the H. influenzae streak line, then factor V is released from S. aureus.

 

It forms larger colonies adjacent to S. aureus streak line and size of the colonies decreases gradually away from the S. aureus streak line, this is known as Satellitism. Therefore, used for the isolation of H. influenzae.

 

 

 

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

 

  1. Factor X = hemin→ present freely in blood
  2. Factor V = Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) →present inside RBCs (also produced by some bacteria, such as Staphylococcus aureus)

 

H. influenzae can cause meningitis, epiglottitis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and less commonly suppurative lesions like arthritis, endocarditis, and pericarditis.

 

DOC - Cefotaxime or ceftazidime

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bacitracin sensitive: Bacitracin sensitivity is a characteristic of Streptococcus pyogenes, a Gram positive coccus.

 

Option B. Produces non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar: Associated with organisms such as Shigella, Salmonella, and Proteus species.

 

Option D. It exhibits alpha hemolysis on sheep blood agar: Alpha-hemolysis on blood agar is a characteristic of Streptococcus pneumonia, a gram-positive coccus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of suspected Haemophilus influenzae infection, particularly meningitis, look for satellitism around Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar, indicating the organism's dependence on externally sourced V factor for growth.

questions.text: What is the most common chemistry of gallstones among the following options? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate

 

Explanation:

 

Gallstones are crystalline formations that occur in the gallbladder due to the precipitation of substances found in bile. The most common type of gallstones are cholesterol stones, which account for about 80% of all gallstone cases. These stones primarily consist of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.

 

Types of Gallstones:

 

  • Cholesterol Stones: These are the most prevalent type, made primarily of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. They are often yellow-green and can vary in size from small grains to large stones.
  • Pigment Stones: Comprising about 20% of gallstones, pigment stones are made of bilirubin and can be either black or brown. These are more likely to form in individuals with liver disease or hemolytic disorders.
  • Mixed Stones: These stones contain both cholesterol and pigment components, and may also include calcium bilirubinate, which is a part of some pigment stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate: This is not a common form of gallstones. Cholesterol stones typically form in the monohydrate crystalline structure rather than dihydrate.

 

Option C. Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate: Gallstones are rarely composed of amorphous cholesterol, and the dihydrate form is not typical. The monohydrate crystalline form is the most common.

 

Option D. Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate: Gallstones are generally crystalline in nature rather than amorphous. Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate is the most common form found in gallstones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common chemistry of gallstones is crystalline cholesterol monohydrate, which constitutes about 80% of all gallstone cases.

choices.text: BCR ABL

questions.text: All-trans retinoic acid is used in the treatment of tumor that is associated with which of the following genetic aberrations? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PML-RARA

 

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML), which is associated with the PML-RARA fusion gene.

 

The long arm of chromosome 17 encodes the retinoic acid alpha receptor gene (RARA). It is primarily expressed in hematopoietic cells and plays an important role in gene expression regulation. RARA is bound by the nuclear corepressor factor in the absence of retinoid acid, causing transcriptional repression. RARA is activated in the presence of retinoic acid, and promyelocytes undergo terminal differentiation.

 

Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is a distinct subtype of acute leukemia distinguished by abnormal promyelocyte proliferation, life-threatening coagulopathy, and the chromosome translocation t (15;17) (q22;q11-12). This results in an abnormal fusion protein known as PML-RARA, which has a low affinity for retinoids. This inhibits transcription and thus prevents gene expression for cellular differentiation. This leads to the accumulation of myeloid progenitor cells.

 

 

Rx: The condition is treated with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA). It binds to the PML-RARA chimeric protein. This causes conformational change such that the protein regains its normal function and activates DNA transcription.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BCR-ABL: Associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

 

  • Treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors like imatinib, not ATRA.

 

Option C. CMYC: Associated with Burkitt lymphoma.

 

  • Involves translocation t (8;14) affecting the c-Myc oncogene.

 

Option D. RUNX1-ETO: Associated with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) with t (8;21).

 

  • Treated with standard chemotherapy regimens, not specifically ATRA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) is used in the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is characterized by the PML-RARA fusion gene resulting from the t(15;17) translocation. This treatment promotes the differentiation of leukemic promyelocytes, improving clinical outcomes in APL patients.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with complaints of progressive loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located in the optic pathway? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

The patient presenting with progressive visual loss in the right halves of both eyes is suggestive of right homonymous hemianopia. The site of the lesion in this case is the left optic tract.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right visual cortex: Lesions in the right visual cortex would cause left homonymous hemianopia, not right. The visual cortex processes information from the contralateral visual field.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: Lesions in the optic chiasma typically cause bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) visual fields in both eyes. This is due to the crossing fibers from the nasal retinas.

 

Option D. Right optic nerve: A lesion in the right optic nerve would cause vision loss in the right eye only, not in both eyes. It would not result in a homonymous visual field defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right homonymous hemianopia, characterized by loss of the right visual field in both eyes, is caused by a lesion in the left optic tract.

questions.text: Components of Disaster cycle that can be included in the recovery phase are: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Response – Rehabilitation – Reconstruction

 

 

The disaster cycle consists of several phases: impact, response, rehabilitation, reconstruction, mitigation, and preparedness.

 

The recovery phase specifically focuses on restoring the affected area to normalcy and includes three key components: Response, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction (Mnemonic: 3Rs). These steps are crucial for rebuilding after a disaster, addressing immediate needs (response), restoring essential services (rehabilitation), and rebuilding infrastructure (reconstruction).

 

Educational Objective:
 

The recovery phase of the disaster cycle includes the components of Response, Rehabilitation, and Reconstruction, which are essential for restoring the community post-disaster.

questions.text: Preferable time for IUCD insertion in a 28-year-old woman who has just delivered a healthy newborn. It was a normal vaginal delivery. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Up to 48 hours

 

Intrauterine Contraceptive Device (IUCD) insertion timing can be categorized into three main periods:

 

  1. During Menstruation: IUCD insertion during menstruation is preferred within the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle to ensure the woman is not pregnant and to ease insertion due to the open cervical os.
  2. Immediate Postpartum: The best time for postpartum IUCD insertion is within the first 48 hours after delivery. If not done within this window, insertion can be performed up to 1 week postpartum. This timing is optimal as the cervix is dilated, and there is a reduced risk of expulsion compared to later periods.
  3. Post Puerperal: If IUCD insertion is not performed immediately postpartum, the next preferred timing is 6 to 8 weeks after delivery when the uterus has involuted and stabilized.

 

For this question, since the woman has just delivered, the most precise and preferred time is within the first 48 hours postpartum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most preferable time for IUCD insertion after a normal vaginal delivery is within the first 48 hours postpartum to take advantage of the naturally dilated cervix and minimize expulsion risk

questions.text: What is the vector for the condition diagnosed by the image shown below? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sandfly

 

The image shown is of the Leishman-Donovan bodies whose presence are diagnostic of Kala Azar. The vector of Kala Azar is a sandfly.

 

Leishman-Donovan bodies are amastigotes with a double dot appearance containing a nucleus and small rodlike kinetoplast. They are present inside the macrophage.

 

The sandfly serves as the vector for Leishmania parasites. When a sandfly bites a human, it can transmit the parasites which then proliferate within the host's macrophages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anopheles mosquito: Incorrect, as this mosquito is the vector for malaria, not Kala Azar.

 

Option B. Ixodes Tick: Incorrect, this tick is a vector for diseases like Lyme disease and not for Kala Azar.

 

Option D. Tsetse fly: Incorrect, as Tsetse flies transmit trypanosomes that cause sleeping sickness, not Leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The presence of Leishman-Donovan bodies inside macrophages is indicative of Kala Azar, a severe form of leishmaniasis transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. Effective prevention and control are critical in endemic regions to reduce the transmission and impact of this disease.

questions.text: A patient presenting with bleeding gums and easy bruisability was diagnosed with scurvy. What is the biochemical basis of scurvy?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defective collagen formation

 

Scurvy is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), which is essential for the hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues in the synthesis of collagen. Collagen is a crucial protein for the structural integrity of connective tissues, including blood vessels, skin, and gums. In the absence of sufficient vitamin C, collagen synthesis is impaired, leading to weakened blood vessels, bleeding gums, and easy bruising..

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low calcium levels do not cause scurvy; they may contribute to other clinical conditions like Muscle cramps and stiffness, Tingling and Numbness, Tetany.

 

Option C. Vitamin K deficiency leads to the inhibition of clotting factors and cause bleeding tendencies.

 

Option D. Vitamin A deficiency causes hyperkeratosis and epithelial changes, such as xerosis and Bitot's spots, and night blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient presenting with multiple humeral shaft fracture, following which he had difficulty in flexion of elbow and supination of forearm. He also complaints of loss of sensation over lateral side of forearm. Which nerve is damaged?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Musculocutaneous nerve

 

MUSCULOCUTANEOUS NERVE (C5, 6, 7)

 

  • It is one of the two terminal branches of the lateral cord, the other being the lateral root of the median nerve.
  • It supplies coracobrachialis, both heads of biceps brachii and most of branchialis, and continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of forearm, running down the lateral aspect of the forearm.
  • Injury to the musculocutaneous nerve results in weakness of supination (biceps) and flexion (biceps, brachialis, and coracobrachialis) of the forearm and loss of sensation on the lateral side of the forearm.
  • It is damaged in shoulder dislocation, second common to axillary nerve.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Median nerve. Median nerve injury is associated with a fracture of the humerus, especially supracondylar fractures. Entrapment at the elbow between the two heads of pronator teres (pronator teres syndrome) and under the flexor retinaculum (carpal tunnel syndrome) are also the causes. Median nerve injury at elbow level causes paralysis of forearm pronators. This keeps the forearm in supine position. When long flexors (except FCU and medial ½ of FDP) are paralyzed, the wrist flexion becomes weak and is accompanied by adduction due to paralysis of FCR and intact FCU. Flexion of terminal phalanx of thumb is lost because of paralysis of FPL. Flexion of interphalangeal joints of index and middle fingers is lost, so there is a pointing index or positive Ochsner clasp or Benediction test.

 

Option C. Axillary nerve. Injured in fracture of surgical neck of humerus, shoulder dislocation (anterior and inferior) and intramuscular injections. There is deltoid muscle palsy, loss of rounded contour of shoulder – giving shoulder a flattened appearance and produce hollow inferior to acromion, weakness of abduction (15-90°), Teres minor palsy, and sensory loss over lower half of deltoid (regimental badge area).

 

Option D. Radial nerve. It is usually injured in fractures of shaft humerus, injection palsy, Saturday night palsy and Crutch palsy. In radial nerve injury, there is sensory loss in the area supplied by the posterior cutaneous nerve of forearm. Wrist, thumb and finger extension is lost i.e., wrist, thumb and fingers drop. Loss of extension of wrist is wrist drop; of thumb is thumb drop; of MCP joint of finger is finger drop.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Difficulty in flexion of elbow and supination of forearm, with loss of sensation over lateral side of forearm are the symptoms associated with musculocutaneous nerve injury.

choices.text: All boys and girl children equally affected
50% boys affected and no girl children unaffected
No boy affected and 50% children are carriers
25% boy affected and 25% girl children are carrier

questions.text: A boy born to a normal father and mother had Hemophilia. Detailed history taking revealed that the mother's side had a family history of similar affected individuals. The children born to this boy are likely to have which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No boy affected and 50% children are carriers

 

Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive disorder, where affected males inherit the defective gene from their carrier mothers. In this scenario, the boy with hemophilia cannot pass the X-linked defective gene to his sons (as they inherit his Y chromosome). Therefore, no male children will be affected.

 

However, all daughters will inherit his X chromosome, meaning that 50% of his children (only daughters and not boys) shall be carriers of the hemophilia gene but will not exhibit the disease because they inherit a normal X chromosome from their mother.

 

Outcome:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. All boys and girl children equally affected: This is incorrect because, due to the X-linked recessive nature of hemophilia, the affected father does not pass the defective X chromosome to his sons.

 

Option B. 50% boys affected and no girl children unaffected: This statement is incorrect as affected fathers cannot transmit the X-linked gene to their sons; only daughters can inherit the X chromosome.

 

Option D. 25% boy affected and 25% girl children are carrier: This does not match the inheritance pattern of X-linked recessive disorders, as male offspring will never inherit the disease from their father, and all daughters will have a 50% chance of being carriers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In X-linked recessive disorders like hemophilia, affected males do not transmit the condition to their sons, but their daughters have a 50% chance of being carriers.

 

Major X-linked Recessive Disorders (Mnemonic: "OBLIGATE"):

 

 

Other X-linked Recessive Diseases:

choices.text: Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place
Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained
Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva manuever and see if the pessary is in place
Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary

questions.text: Which of the following is the first step after fitting the pessary to check if the pessary is adequately retained? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Asking the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary is in place

 

Explanation:

 

 

 

A vaginal pessary is a device used to support the pelvic organs in women with uterovaginal prolapse who are either unfit for surgery or unwilling to undergo surgery. The fitting process involves several steps to ensure the pessary is comfortable and effective:

 

  1. Patient Preparation: The patient is positioned in the lithotomy position and should have an empty bladder and rectum.
  2. Vaginal Examination: An assessment of vaginal length and width is performed to estimate the appropriate pessary size.
  3. Insertion: The pessary is lubricated and inserted in a cephalad direction against the posterior vaginal wall.
  4. Placement Check: An index finger is directed into the posterior vaginal fornix to ensure the cervix is above the pessary, and the pessary should fit snugly against the vaginal walls without causing pain.
  5. Adequacy Check: The patient is asked to perform a Valsalva maneuver (forceful exhalation against a closed airway) to see if the pessary remains in place, ensuring it is not dislodged during increased intra-abdominal pressure.
  6. Functionality Check: The patient should be able to stand, walk, cough, and urinate without difficulty or discomfort.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Asking the patient to void and see if the pessary is in place: While checking the ability to void is important, it is not the first step after fitting the pessary.

 

Option B. Seeing if the patient feels any discomfort, which means that the pessary is retained: Patient comfort is crucial, but discomfort does not necessarily mean the pessary is adequately retained.

 

Option D. Being able to admit two fingers between the ring and the pessary: This is not a standard method for checking the fit of a pessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After fitting a pessary, the first step to check if it is adequately retained is to ask the patient to perform the Valsalva maneuver and see if the pessary remains in place.

choices.text: Collect water from already leaking taps
Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute
Water sample container is kept close to the tap avoid spillage
Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

questions.text: How is water collected for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination, especially during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to follow proper procedures to avoid contamination and ensure the sample's accuracy. The best practice is to collect water from a gentle stream to avoid splashing, which can introduce contaminants from the environment into the sample.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Collect water from already leaking tape: Not recommended as it could contaminate the sample and may lead to false results.

 

Option B. Before collecting, let water flow for at least 1 minute: Before collecting, let water flow for at least 2 minutes

 

Option C. Water sample container is kept close to the tap to avoid spillage: It is a good practice but this practice alone does not ensure the proper collection of the sample.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When collecting water for bacteriological examination during a disease outbreak, it is crucial to collect from a gentle stream of water to avoid splashing and potential contamination. This practice ensures the accuracy and reliability of the water sample.

questions.text: Based on the agglutination test shown below, what is the blood group?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. O positive

 

The agglutination test is a blood test used to determine an individual's blood type. In the case of O positive blood, the test involves mixing a sample of the person's blood with two different types of antibodies: anti-A and anti-B.

 

The person's blood cells do not agglutinate in the presence of either antibody, it indicates that the person's blood type is O positive. This means that the person's blood cells do not contain either the A or B antigen, but do contain the Rh factor antigen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B positive: Incorrect because there is no agglutination in the B panel, indicating the absence of B antigens.

 

Option B. A positive: Incorrect as there is no agglutination in the A panel, indicating the absence of A antigens.

 

Option D. AB positive: Incorrect because there is no agglutination in both A and B panels, which would be required for AB blood type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of agglutination with anti-A and anti-B antibodies and the presence of agglutination with anti-Rh antibodies confirms the blood group as O positive. This means the individual's red blood cells lack A and B antigens but contain the Rh factor.

questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

The patient with given symptoms and lab results, points out to diagnosis of dengue fever.

 

Dengue, aka Break Bone Fever

 

 

Shown below is an image of the rash in dengue:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria patients presents with clinical features like periodic bouts of fever with chills and rigors, followed by anemia, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Scrub typhus patients typically presents with a characteristic eschar, which is a punched-out ulcer covered with a blackened scab at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash. Here’s an image of the eschar.

 

 

Option D. Typhoid (enteric) fever presents with fever, abdominal pain, headache, chills, myalgia, malaise, diarrhea, sweating, nausea, and vomiting. Rose spots are classical, pink macules on the abdomen and the chest. Hepatosplenomegaly and relative bradycardia might be seen. The WBC count vary from normal to low.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of fever, arthralgia, petechial rash, and significant thrombocytopenia in a patient from an area where dengue is endemic should prompt immediate consideration of dengue fever, with prompt initiation of supportive care and monitoring for potential complications such as DHF or DSS.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the ER in a state of unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg and her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of her condition? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synchronized cardioversion

 

Any hemodynamically unstable rhythm, requires synchronized cardioversion (Shock delivered in sync with R wave to prevent R-on-T phenomenon)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: AV Nodal blockers are used if hemodynamically stable.

 

Option B: Maximum of 30mg of adenosine can be tried if patient is Hemodynamically Stable.

 

Option C: Carotid massage is not recommended for hemodynamically unstable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: It is detected in blood during sepsis
It is produced in response to bacterial infection.
It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding neutrophil extracellular trapping (NET)? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mitochondrial DNA is seen

 

Mitochondrial DNA is not seen in neutrophil extracellular traps (NET). In classic NETosis, the DNA is nuclear, not mitochondrial.

 

Some rare reports suggest that under certain non-lytic forms, mitochondrial DNA may be extruded, but this is not typical of NETs as understood in bacterial infections or sepsis.

 

Neutrophilic extracellular traps (NET) are a network of neutrophil nuclear chromatin/DNA. The death of neutrophils is caused by the loss of nuclei. They assemble antimicrobial peptides and enzymes to combat bacteria and fungi (not viruses). During sepsis, they are detected in the blood.

 

They are produced by neutrophils in response to:

 

  • Infectious pathogens: mainly bacteria and fungi
  • Inflammatory mediators: chemokines, cytokines (mainly interferons), complement proteins, and reactive oxygen species (ROS)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is detected in blood during sepsis:

 

  • True Statement: NETs are indeed detected in the blood during sepsis as part of the body's response to widespread infection.

 

Option B. It is produced in response to bacterial infection:

 

  • True Statement: NETs are produced in response to bacterial infection as well as fungal infections.

 

Option D. It is chromatin with antibacterial enzymes:

 

  • True Statement: NETs consist of chromatin (DNA) along with antibacterial enzymes and peptides, which help in trapping and killing pathogens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are networks of nuclear DNA from neutrophils combined with antimicrobial enzymes and peptides, produced in response to bacterial and fungal infections. They play a crucial role in trapping and neutralizing pathogens. The presence of mitochondrial DNA in NETs is incorrect, as NETs are composed of nuclear chromatin.

questions.text: A pituitary tumor that overproduced growth hormone was surgically removed from a patient. The resection was discovered to be insufficient. What is the patient's first-line treatment? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Octreotide

 

Octreotide is a synthetic somatostatin analog that inhibits the secretion of growth hormone (GH) from the pituitary gland. It is the first-line treatment for patients with acromegaly when surgery alone is insufficient to control GH levels. Octreotide binds to somatostatin receptors, reducing GH production and controlling symptoms of acromegaly.

 


Other Options:

 

Option A. Leuprolide: Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist primarily used in the treatment of hormone-sensitive cancers such as prostate cancer, and conditions like endometriosis and uterine fibroids. It is not used for reducing GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Option B. Goserelin: Goserelin is another GnRH agonist used for similar indications as leuprolide, including prostate cancer and breast cancer, as well as for managing endometriosis. It is not indicated for GH reduction in acromegaly.

 

Option C. Nafarelin: Nafarelin also a GnRH agonist, is used for the treatment of endometriosis and central precocious puberty. Like the other GnRH agonists, it is not used to manage GH levels in acromegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Octreotide is used for the treatment of the following conditions: (SOMATostatin)

 

S: Secretory diarrhea due to carcinoid tumor, VIPomas, following cancer chemotherapy, AIDS etc.

 

O: Oesophageal varices (Acute Variceal bleeding)

 

M: Malignancy like Insulinoma and Glucagonoma

 

A: Acromegaly due to GH secreting pituitary adenoma

 

T: Thyrotrope adenoma

 

  • Leuprolide, Goeserelin and Nafarelin are GnRH agonists.

questions.text: ASEPSIS wound scoring takes all of the following into consideration except: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Induration

 

ASEPSIS wound score does not take induration into consideration.

 

ASEPSIS wound score and Southampton wound score are used to determine the severity of the surgical site wound infection (SSI).

 

ASEPSIS SCORE

 

 

Criterion Not Included: 

 

Option D. Induration: Induration (hardening of the tissue) is not included in the ASEPSIS wound scoring system. The criteria focus on discharge, erythema, separation of tissues, bacterial isolation, and additional treatments rather than tissue induration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ASEPSIS wound scoring system does not include induration as a criterion. It focuses on factors like purulent and serous discharge, erythema, separation of deep tissue, additional treatments, bacterial isolation, and extended hospital stay to evaluate surgical site infections.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases have autosomal recessive inheritance? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albinism

 

Albinism is typically inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. To have albinism, an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene for albinism, one from each parent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. G-6-PD deficiency: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G-6-PD) deficiency is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner, not autosomal recessive. It affects males more often than females.

 

Option C. Marfan's syndrome: Marfan's syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, not autosomal recessive. A single copy of the mutated gene from one parent is enough to cause the condition.

 

Option D. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. It primarily affects males who inherit the mutated gene from their carrier mothers.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of vesicular oral lesions, and on skin sample, DIF showed a fishnet pattern as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by the formation of vesicles and bullae, particularly on mucous membranes such as the oral cavity. The disease is caused by autoantibodies against desmogleins (desmosomal proteins) that hold keratinocytes together. This results in acantholysis, where keratinocytes lose their adhesion, leading to intraepidermal blister formation.

 

The direct immunofluorescence (DIF) of a biopsy from perilesional skin in pemphigus vulgaris typically shows a "fishnet" or "chicken wire" pattern, which is due to the deposition of IgG antibodies along the keratinocyte cell membranes. The image provided in the question clearly demonstrates this characteristic pattern, which is pathognomonic for pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bullous pemphigoid: This is another autoimmune blistering disorder, but it primarily affects older adults and presents with subepidermal blisters rather than intraepidermal ones. The DIF pattern in bullous pemphigoid typically shows a linear deposition of IgG and C3 along the basement membrane zone, not a fishnet pattern.

 

Option C. LIGA: This option seems to be a distractor as there is no recognized dermatological condition by this acronym. This might be a typographical error or a non-standard term, hence it is not relevant to this question.

 

Option D. Dermatitis herpetiformis: This is a chronic blistering skin condition associated with gluten sensitivity (celiac disease). The DIF pattern in dermatitis herpetiformis typically shows granular deposits of IgA at the tips of the dermal papillae, not a fishnet pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is associated with a characteristic "fishnet" pattern on direct immunofluorescence due to IgG deposition along keratinocyte cell membranes. Recognizing this pattern is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient presenting with neck stiffness and severe headache with CT showing blood in the basal cistern suggests towards the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is an extra axial intracranial hemorrhage and denotes the presence of blood within the subarachnoid space. NCCT shows the hyperdense “star of death” appearance.

 

The modified Fisher scale is a grading method for SAH as seen on non-contrast CT (NCCT). The Hunt and Hess scale is used to describe the severity of SAH and to predict survival.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Meningitis can also present with neck stiffness and headache. NCCT would be normal. CE-MRI shows thickened enhancing meninges.

 

Option C: Intraparenchymal hemorrhage is acute accumulation of blood within the parenchyma of the brain and on CT scan a hyperdense collection of blood, often with surrounding hypodense edema.

 

Option D: Hemorrhagic stroke is a broader classification and usually indicated IC bleed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage is a critical condition indicated by CT findings of blood in the subarachnoid space, presenting clinically with rapid onset headache and neck stiffness. It requires immediate medical attention and further evaluation with grading scales like the modified Fisher scale to assess severity and guide treatment.

questions.text: Identify the mask in the image below? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Non-rebreathing mask

 

The oxygen delivery device shown in the image above is a non-rebreathing mask (NRBM).

 

Non-rebreathing mask (NRBM):

  • The non-rebreathing mask provides high concentrations of oxygen. It features a reservoir bag attached to it, which helps in providing a high flow of oxygen.
  • The mask has one-way valves that prevent exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring that only oxygen is inhaled.
  • The maximum FiO2 given by an NRBM is approximately 80%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: A Venturi mask is designed to deliver a precise oxygen concentration. It has interchangeable valves that regulate the amount of oxygen and ambient air mix, providing specific FiO2 levels. It is typically used when controlled oxygen therapy is required.

 

 

 

Option B. Hudson mask: The Hudson mask, also known as a simple face mask, delivers oxygen concentrations ranging from 40% to 60%. It does not have a reservoir bag and is less precise in delivering a specific oxygen concentration compared to the Venturi mask.

 

 

Option C. Nebulizer mask: A nebulizer mask is used to deliver aerosolized medications (such as bronchodilators) to patients. It is attached to a nebulizer machine, which converts liquid medication into a fine mist for inhalation. This mask is not primarily used for oxygen delivery.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask (NRBM) is an oxygen delivery device that provides high concentrations of oxygen, up to approximately 80%, and is characterized by a reservoir bag and one-way valves to ensure the inhalation of high-purity oxygen.

questions.text: Stoss therapy is utilized for the treatment of which condition? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Vitamin D deficiency rickets

 

Explanation:

 

Stoss therapy refers to the administration of a large single dose or a few divided doses of vitamin D for the rapid correction of vitamin D deficiency. This therapy is specifically designed for treating nutritional vitamin D deficiency rickets. It typically involves giving a high dose of vitamin D (typically 300,000-600,000 IU) as either a single dose or divided over a few days.

 

The advantages of Stoss therapy include improved compliance (as it requires fewer doses) and rapid correction of deficiency. After the initial high-dose therapy, maintenance doses of vitamin D are continued to prevent recurrence. This approach is particularly useful in situations where compliance with daily supplementation might be challenging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scurvy - Incorrect. Scurvy is caused by vitamin C deficiency and is treated with vitamin C supplementation (100-200 mg/day for 3 months), not high-dose vitamin D therapy.

 

Option B. Keratomalacia - Incorrect. Keratomalacia is a condition resulting from severe vitamin A deficiency affecting the cornea. It requires vitamin A supplementation, not vitamin D. Treatment usually involves 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally on day 1, repeated on day 2 and after 2 weeks.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemic rickets - Incorrect. Hypophosphatemic rickets (vitamin D-resistant rickets) is typically hereditary and caused by phosphate wasting, not vitamin D deficiency. It is treated with phosphate supplements and calcitriol, not high-dose vitamin D therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stoss therapy is specifically used for treating vitamin D deficiency rickets with large doses (300,000-600,000 IU) given over a short period, providing rapid correction and improved compliance compared to daily supplementation regimens.

questions.text: A woman presents to the OPD with complaints of amenorrhoea for the past year. She has a history of postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sheehan’s syndrome

 

  • The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Sheehan's syndrome.
  • When postpartum hemorrhage causes vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels (pituitary apoplexy) and panhypopituitarism. It is characterized by:
    • Lactation failure - due to prolactin deficiency
    • Amenorrhea - due to anovulation caused by reduced gonadotropin activity
    • Loss of sexual and axillary hair
    • Hypothyroidism - due to decreased TSH secretion
    • Adrenal insufficiency - due to low ACTH

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rotor Syndrome: Also known as Rotor type hyperbilirubinemia, is an autosomal recessive disease and a rare cause of mixed direct (conjugated) and indirect (unconjugated) hyperbilirubinemia. The disease is characterized by non-hemolytic jaundice due to chronic elevation of predominantly conjugated bilirubin

 

Option C. Prolactinoma: This will not present lactation failure. Instead, there will be galactorrhea and symptoms like headache, luring of vision due to pressure effects of the prolactinoma.

 

Option D. Acromegaly: It is a disorder that results in excess growth of certain parts of the human body. It is caused by excess growth hormone (GH) after the growth plates have closed. The initial symptom is typically enlargement of the hands and feet. There may also be an enlargement of the forehead, jaw, and nose. Other symptoms may include joint pain, thicker skin, deepening of the voice, headaches, and problems with vision. Complications of the disease may include type 2 diabetes, sleep apnea, and high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan’s syndrome is characterized by postpartum hemorrhage leading to vascular thrombosis of the pituitary vessels, resulting in panhypopituitarism with symptoms like lactation failure and amenorrhea.

 

Ref: Page no 458, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency room with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. After being administered an intravenous drug for treatment, he develops abnormal movements. Which of the following medications can be used to manage his abnormal movements? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benzhexol

 

Benzhexol (also known as trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic agent often used to treat extrapyramidal symptoms, which include abnormal involuntary movements. These symptoms can occur as a side effect of D2 blockers like antipsychotics and some antiemetics like metoclopramide that may have been used to treat the vomiting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoscine: This is an antispasmodic and anticholinergic drug mainly used for motion sickness and gastrointestinal spasms. It is not specifically used for treating abnormal movements such as extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option B. Cyproheptadine: This is an antihistamine and anticholinergic medication used mainly for allergic reactions. It is not primarily indicated for the treatment of abnormal movements.

 

Option C. Levodopa: This medication is primarily used for treating Parkinson's disease and is not indicated for the treatment of drug-induced abnormal movements unless those symptoms are related to Parkinson’s disease.

 

Therefore, in this patient who developed abnormal movements possibly due to a drug side effect, Benzhexol would be the appropriate medication for managing his symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) is the drug of choice for managing extrapyramidal symptoms, which include abnormal movements induced by medications such as D2 receptor blockers.

questions.text: Which cardiac chamber enlargement is seen in the case of mitral stenosis on chest X-ray initially? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left atrium

 

In the case of mitral stenosis (MS), the obstruction at the mitral valve leads to increased pressure in the left atrium as it works harder to pump blood through the narrowed valve. This increased pressure causes the left atrium to dilate. This dilation can be identified on a chest X-ray as enlargement of the left atrial silhouette. The left atrium enlargement is often the earliest and most prominent cardiac chamber change seen in mitral stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrium: Right atrium enlargement generally occurs later in the course of mitral stenosis as a consequence of the elevated pressure being transmitted back through the lungs to the right side of the heart.

 

Option C. Left ventricle: The left ventricle is typically not directly affected by mitral stenosis, as this condition primarily impacts the left atrium. Left ventricular enlargement would be more characteristic of conditions affecting the left ventricular outflow or volume overload.

 

Option D. Right ventricle: Right ventricular enlargement may eventually occur if the disease progresses to the point of causing pulmonary hypertension, which then puts a strain on the right ventricle. However, this is a later development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitral stenosis primarily leads to enlargement of the left atrium as the initial response to increased pressure upstream of the stenotic mitral valve. Recognition of this early sign on a chest X-ray can be crucial for diagnosing and managing mitral stenosis effectively.

 

Reference - Harrison/Cardiology/VHD

questions.text: 100-day glaucoma is seen in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Central retinal vein occlusion

 

  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) is also known as "90-" or "100-day glaucoma" due to its typical development 3 months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO).
  • NVG results from the occlusion of the central retinal vein, causing significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis.
  • Recurrent hemorrhages are common, and neovascularization of the retina and optic disc develop.
  • The retina undergoes pigmentary and atrophic changes.
  • NVG occurs in three stages:
    1. Pre-glaucomatous stage - stage of rubeosis iridis i.e. neovascularisation on the surface of the iris.
    2. Open-angle glaucoma stage - due to the formation of a pretrabecular neovascular membrane.
    3. Secondary angle closure glaucoma— due to goniosynechiae resulting from contracture of the neovascular membrane (zipper-angle closure).

 

 

  • Treatment of NVG is usually frustrating.
    • Pan-retinal photocoagulation may be carried out to prevent further neovascularization.
    • Medical therapy and conventional filtration surgery are usually not effective in controlling the IOP.
    • Artificial filtration shunt (valved/unvalved) may control the IOP.
  • Serious complications of central retinal vein occlusion are cystoid degeneration of the macula, optic atrophy, and hemorrhagic or neovascular glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Eale’s disease: Eales disease, also known as "primary retinal periphlebitis" or "periphlebitis retinae," is a rare inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the blood vessels in the retina of the eye. It was first described by the British ophthalmologist Henry Eales in 1880, and the condition was subsequently named after him.

 

Eales disease typically occurs in young adults, often males, and is more prevalent in certain regions, including India. The exact cause of Eales disease is not well understood, but it is believed to have an immunological basis. Some theories suggest that it may be related to immune system dysfunction, possibly triggered by an underlying infection or other factors.

 

The main features of Eales disease include:

 

  1. Retinal Vasculitis: Inflammation of the small blood vessels (veins) in the retina. This can lead to retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and swelling, which can affect vision.
  2. Neovascularization: New, abnormal blood vessels may develop as a response to the damaged retinal vessels. These abnormal vessels can be fragile and prone to bleeding, leading to further vision problems.
  3. Vitreous Hemorrhage:
  4. Retinal Detachment: In some cases, Eales disease can lead to tractional retinal detachment.

 

The symptoms of Eales disease can vary and may include blurred vision, floaters, and reduced visual acuity. Diagnosis is typically made through a thorough clinical examination, which may include the use of imaging techniques like fundus fluorescein angiography to visualize the areas of capillary non-perfusion, leakage (suggestive of neovascularisation or macular edema).

 

The treatment of Eales disease aims to control inflammation, prevent or treat complications, and preserve or improve vision. Treatment options may include systemic or local corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and macular edema, intravitreal Anti VEGF injection for macular edema, laser photocoagulation therapy to target abnormal blood vessels, and in some cases, surgical intervention (pars plana vitrectomy) to address complications like retinal detachment and vitreous haemorrhage. The specific treatment plan will depend on the severity of the disease and the individual patient's needs.

 

It's important for individuals with Eales disease to receive ongoing care and follow-up with an ophthalmologist to monitor their condition and manage any potential complications. Causative association with tuberculosis is present and patient needs to be evaluated for TB and AKT may be initiated where indicated.

 

Option C. Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) is a medical condition that occurs when the central retinal artery becomes blocked or narrowed. This blockage results in a sudden and severe loss of vision in the affected eye. CRAO is considered a medical emergency because it can lead to permanent vision loss if not treated promptly.

 

Common causes and risk factors of central retinal artery occlusion include:

 

  1. Atherosclerosis: The most common cause of CRAO is atherosclerosis.
  2. Embolism:
  3. Giant cell arteritis: This is a condition in which the arteries, including the central retinal artery, become inflamed. It primarily affects older individuals and can result in CRAO. GCA is an emergency requiring prompt initiation of systemic steroids to prevent the fellow eye from developing CRAO.
  4. Vasculitis: Occlusive inflammation of the blood vessels can lead to occlusion of the central retinal artery.

 

Symptoms of central retinal artery occlusion may include:

 

  1. Sudden, painless, and severe vision loss in one eye.
  2. The affected eye may appear pale or whitened (retinal pallor).
  3. RAPD.
  4. Cherry-red spot: Due to the contrast between the well-oxygenated macula and the poorly oxygenated surrounding retina.

 

Treatment options may include:

 

  1. Ocular massage: to dislodge the embolus causing the blockage.
  2. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Breathing pure oxygen in a pressurized chamber can increase oxygen delivery to the retina and may be considered in some cases.
  3. Carbogen inhalation therapy or rebreathing into a paper bag – Resultant hypercarbemia causes vasodilation which may help to dislodge the embolus and restore blood flow.
  4. Reducing intraocular pressure – by means of Anterior Chamber paracentesis or systemic acetazolamide.
  5. Surgical intervention: Optic Nerve Sheath fenestration surgery.
  6. Thrombolytic therapy: In some situations, clot-dissolving medications may be used.

 

Option D. Steroid-induced glaucoma:

 

  • Description: Glaucoma resulting from prolonged use of corticosteroids.
  • Mechanism: Steroids can increase IOP by reducing the outflow of aqueous humor.
  • Symptoms: Gradual loss of peripheral vision, halos around lights, headache, eye pain.
  • Treatment: Reducing or discontinuing steroid use, using IOP-lowering medications.

  • Note: Steroid-induced glaucoma is not associated with neovascularization or termed as 100-day glaucoma.

     

Educational Objective:

 

Neovascular glaucoma, known as "100-day glaucoma," typically develops about three months after the onset of Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) due to significant retinal ischemia and venous stasis leading to neovascularization.

questions.text: A 19-year-old youth was brought the casualty with a black eye following a fist fight. Which area of the orbit is most likely to have been fractured? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Floor

 

  • The most common site of an orbital blowout fracture is the floor of the orbit.
  • BLOW-out fractures involve LOW wall (means inferior wall or floor of orbit).
  • The floor consists of three bones: the zygomatic, maxillary, and palatine bones. The posteromedial portion of the maxillary bone is relatively weak and may be involved in a "blowout" fracture.
  • Clinical features:
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema affecting the eyelids (commoner with medial wall fractures)
  • Enophthalmus (inward displacement of eyeball) and mechanical ptosis
  • Infraorbital nerve anaesthesia
  • Double diplopia (diplopia in both upwards as well as downwards gaze)
  • Positive “forced duction test”
  • Management:
  • X ray (Waters view) and CT-Scan of orbit show tear drop sign.
  • Conservative management may be useful in a good number of patients.
  • However, surgical intervention if required should be done about 2 weeks of injury with synthetic material like supramide, teflon or silicon.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial wall: Less commonly involved in isolated blowout fractures; can be associated with subcutaneous emphysema.

 

Option B. Lateral wall: The strongest wall of the orbit and less likely to fracture in isolated blunt trauma.

 

Option C. Roof: More common in children due to its thinness but less common overall compared to the floor in blowout fractures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The floor of the orbit is the most likely site of fracture in cases of orbital blowout fractures resulting from blunt trauma, such as a fist fight. Key clinical features include enophthalmos, infraorbital nerve anesthesia, and diplopia. Imaging with X-rays and CT scans are crucial for diagnosis and surgical intervention may be required for severe cases.

choices.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.text: A toddler was found playing alone and was brought to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the past few hours. An X-ray was performed, and the image revealed as shown in AP view. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Foreign body in the esophagus

 

  • A child presenting with difficulty in swallowing and the given X-ray suggest a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin or disc battery.
  • Anteroposterior (AP) and lateral views of the chest and neck X-rays were taken, and the flat surface of the coin in the esophagus is seen on the AP view, while the edge is seen on the lateral view.
  • Initial symptoms of esophageal foreign body ingestion include choking, gagging, and coughing, followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat.
  • Respiratory symptoms such as stridor, wheezing, cyanosis, or dyspnea may also be seen.
  • Correct. If an object gets lodged in the esophagus, it can cause difficulty swallowing, pain, and drooling. The scenario presented indicates an X-ray showing a radiopaque foreign body (likely a coin or disc battery) in the esophagus, which is consistent with the child's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body in the trachea: When a foreign body is stuck in the trachea, it is a life-threatening situation as it can block airflow. Symptoms would typically include coughing, choking, wheezing, and difficulty breathing. The flat surface would be better seen in the lateral view.

 

Option C. Artifact: An artifact in radiology refers to any distortion or error in the image that is not present in the patient. Artifacts can be due to the equipment, the patient's movement, or other factors.

 

Option D. Soft tissue calcification in the neck: This refers to the presence of calcified deposits in the soft tissues of the neck. These can be due to various reasons, such as long-standing inflammation, tumors, or other diseases. However, the presentation of acute difficulty in swallowing and the X-ray findings make this option unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of pediatric ingestion of foreign bodies, the esophagus is a common site where objects can become lodged.
  • Radiographic evaluation typically shows a foreign body in the esophagus with a flat surface seen on the AP view and the edge on the lateral view.
  •  Immediate recognition and appropriate intervention are crucial to prevent complications.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with 34 weeks of amenorrhea has the following findings: LDH - 700 IU/L, platelets - 75,000/ mm3, serum bilirubin - 1.5 mg/dL, SGOT - 200 U/L, SGPT - 150 U/L, and BP - 140/96 mm Hg. Her coagulation profile and renal function tests are normal. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HELLP syndrome

 

HELLP Syndrome:

 

  • The given clinical scenario with elevated liver enzymes (SGOT and SGPT), elevated bilirubin, low platelet count, and hypertension is indicative of HELLP syndrome.
  • HELLP is an acronym for:
    • Hemolysis (H): Evidence of hemolysis can include elevated LDH.
    • Elevated Liver enzymes (EL): Both SGOT and SGPT are elevated.
    • Low Platelet count (LP): Platelet count is significantly reduced (below 100,000/mm³).
  • This syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia and requires immediate medical attention.
  • Management often involves the termination of pregnancy, with steroid cover for fetal lung maturity and magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for seizure prophylaxis and neuroprotection of the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy:

 

  • This condition typically occurs during the late second and third trimesters.
  • Diagnosis is based on the Swansea Criteria, requiring 6 or more specific findings, which often include renal impairment, liver impairment, hypoglycemia, and coagulation defects.
  • Liver biopsy would show microvascular steatosis.

 

 

Option C. Viral Hepatitis:

 

  • Viral hepatitis can occur at any gestational age and presents with jaundice.
  • It typically involves markedly elevated bilirubin and significantly raised SGOT and SGPT levels.
  • This scenario lacks the characteristic very high bilirubin levels seen in viral hepatitis.

 

Option D. Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy:

 

  • Usually occurs in the third trimester and presents with pruritus.
  • Lab findings typically show mildly elevated bilirubin, elevated SGOT and SGPT, and characteristically raised serum bile acids.
  • Renal impairment, high BP, and coagulation abnormalities are not seen in intrahepatic cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HELLP syndrome is characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. It is a severe form of preeclampsia and necessitates urgent medical intervention.

 

Ref: Page no 1809, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Name the drug that acts on both the marked points: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Omapatrilat

 

Omapatrilat is a inhibits both neprilysin and Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE). As a result, there is a decrease in Angiotensin II and increase in natriuretic peptide levels, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, vasodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sacubitril: Sacubitril inhibits neprilysin reducing breakdown of vasoactive peptides such as natriuretic peptides and bradykinin, therefore increasing their levels leading to vasodilation, diuresis, and counteracting the effects of RAAS. Sacubitril is combined with an ARB, valsartan is indicated for the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).

 

Option C. Losartan: Losartan is classified under angiotensin receptor blocker, used in the treatment of hypertension. A/E are Hyperkalemia, Dysgeusia, Postural hypotension. C/I in pregnancy, B/L Renal Artery Stenosis. Losartan decreases serum uric acid levels.

 

Option D. Nesiritide: Nesiritide is a synthetic brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), acts as a natriuretic and vasodilator. Primarily used in acute decompensated heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omapatrilat inhibits both neprilysin and angiotensin-converting enzyme, thereby decreasing angiotensin II and increasing natriuretic peptides, promoting natriuresis, diuresis, and vasodilation.

questions.text: Which Reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bainbridge reflex

 

Explanation

 

Bainbridge reflex is a cardioaccelerator reflex that increases the heart rate when venous return is increased. Since this reflex arises from right atrium, it is also called right atrial reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. J Reflex: Apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension due to J receptor (C-receptor, juxta-pulmonary capillary receptor) stimulation.

 

Option B. Cushing Reflex: Incorrect because the Cushing reflex involves increased blood pressure, bradycardia, and respiratory depression in response to increased intracranial pressure, not right atrial distension.

 

Option C. Bezold-Jarisch Reflex: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is the reflex characterized by bradycardia and hypotension, caused by stimulation of chemoreceptors present in the wall of left ventricles by substances such as alkaloids. It is also called coronary chemoreflex. Vagal fibers form the afferent and efferent pathways of this reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for inducing tachycardia in response to right atrial distension. It serves to adjust heart rate upward when venous return to the heart increases, ensuring optimal cardiac output and circulation efficiency.

questions.text: Scenario with primary amenorrhea with secondary sexual characters present, uterus and ovaries present with an image as shown. What is the likely karyotype? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 46 XX

 

The scenario describes a patient with primary amenorrhea, secondary sexual characteristics, and a presence of the uterus and ovaries. The image shows an obstruction in the vaginal opening, which is likely an imperforate hymen. The presence of secondary sexual characteristics and normal internal reproductive organs, such as the uterus and ovaries, indicates that the chromosomal pattern is normal female, 46 XX. The karyotype is not affected by the physical obstruction causing the amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:
