Option A. 45 XO: This karyotype is characteristic of Turner syndrome, where patients usually have streak ovaries, lack secondary sexual characteristics, and have other distinct features like webbed neck and short stature, none of which are present in this scenario.

 

Option C. 47 XXY: This karyotype corresponds to Klinefelter syndrome, typically found in males who present with hypogonadism, tall stature, and often gynecomastia. It is not applicable to the described scenario with a female presentation.

 

Option D. 46 XY: This karyotype is associated with male individuals or conditions like Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome. The presence of normal female internal reproductive structures (uterus and ovaries) rules out 46 XY.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea with normal development of secondary sexual characteristics and intact internal female reproductive organs (uterus and ovaries) generally indicates a normal female karyotype, 46 XX.

questions.text: A veterinarian developed an ulcer with central black eschar over the forearm as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacillus anthracis

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cutaneous anthrax which is caused by Bacillus anthracis.

 

Human anthrax presents in one of three ways:

 

  • ﻿﻿Cutaneous Anthrax (hide porter's disease)- Black eschar at the base, with a very prominent inflammatory ring around the eschar, is referred to as a malignant pustule.
  • ﻿﻿Pulmonary Anthrax (Wool sorter's disease) - Hemorrhagic pneumonia.
  • ﻿﻿Intestinal Anthrax- Hemorrhagic diarrhoea. It occurs mainly in primitive communities that eat the carcasses of animals dying of anthrax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Known for causing infections in wounds and burns, often producing a greenish pus but not typically associated with black eschars.

 

Option B. Yersinia pestis: Causes bubonic plague, associated with swollen and painful lymph nodes (buboes) rather than black eschars.

 

Option D. Francisella tularensis: Causes tularemia, which can present with ulcers at the infection site but lacks the characteristic black eschar of anthrax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutaneous anthrax is characterized by the initial appearance of a small pimple that quickly turns into a painless ulcer with a necrotic (black) eschar at the center. This presentation is typical for individuals who have been in contact with infected animals or animal products, which is common in the veterinary profession.

 

Additional Information

 

Robert Koch validated the germ theory of disease after discovering the anthrax bacillus as the cause of anthrax. He also discovered the causative agents of tuberculosis and cholera. Hence, he is Known as the Father of Bacteriology.

 

Koch's postulates, which link specific microorganisms to specific diseases, state that the microorganism must be:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Found in abundance in diseased organisms, but not in healthy organisms.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Isolated from a diseased organism and grown in pure culture
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Able to cause disease when inoculated into a healthy organism
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Re-isolated from the diseased experimental host and identical to the original specific causative agent

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kawasaki disease

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.

 

KAWASAKI DISEASE MNEMONIC

 

CRASH & Burn

 

  • Conjunctivitis (non-purulent)
  • Rash
  • Adenopathy (cervical and commonly unilateral)
  • Strawberry tongue
  • Hands (palmar erythema/ swelling)
  • Burn (fever lasting at least 5 days or more)

 

The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction.

 

Rx: Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Option D. Henoch-Schönlein purpura is an acute, systemic, immune complex-mediated, leukocytoclastic vasculitis. It is characterized by a clinical triad of palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia), abdominal pain, and arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is characterized by a persistent fever, erythematous and polymorphous rash, edema of hands and feet, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. It primarily affects children under 4 years old and can lead to serious coronary artery complications if not treated appropriately.

questions.text: A 25-year-old software engineer presented with fatigue and lethargy. He worked for 12-14 hours a day, and his diet pattern consisted predominantly of fast food with very little veggies and greens. Labs: Hb - 9, MCV 106. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Folate deficiency

 

The patient presents with macrocytic anemia, indicated by an MCV of 106. Macrocytic anemia is often caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate. The patient's dietary habits, which include a diet predominantly of fast food with very little vegetables and greens, suggest a lack of dietary folate.

 

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Typically occurs in individuals who do not consume animal products (vegans). This deficiency is less likely in this patient due to the absence of such a dietary restriction.
  • Folate deficiency: Common in individuals with poor intake of vegetables and greens. This matches the patient's dietary pattern.
  • Iron deficiency: Results in microcytic anemia (MCV < 80), not macrocytic anemia.
  • Hemolytic anemia: Usually presents as normocytic anemia (MCV 80-100) with increased reticulocyte count and elevated LDH, which does not match the lab findings of this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B12 deficiency: While B12 deficiency causes macrocytic anemia, it is more common in individuals who avoid animal products. The patient's history does not indicate a dietary restriction on animal products.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency causes microcytic anemia (low MCV), which is not consistent with the patient's lab findings of an MCV of 106.

 

Option D. Hemolytic anemia: Hemolytic anemia typically presents with normocytic anemia and increased reticulocyte count, not with the high MCV seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folate deficiency should be considered in patients with macrocytic anemia and poor dietary intake of vegetables and greens. This deficiency can cause fatigue and lethargy and is confirmed by a high MCV and dietary history.

questions.text: A child presented with leukocoria and an intraocular mass, which on histopathological examination had the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis in the child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children. The classical presentation includes leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and an intraocular mass. Histopathologically, the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes is a key diagnostic feature of retinoblastoma. These rosettes are true rosettes characterized by a circular arrangement of tumor cells around an empty lumen, resembling a flower.

 

In this case:

 

  • Leukocoria is a typical clinical presentation of retinoblastoma.
  • The intraocular mass in a child further supports this diagnosis.
  • The presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes confirms the diagnosis, as they are pathognomonic for retinoblastoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Melanoma: While melanoma can occur in the eye, it is more common in adults and typically does not present with leukocoria or Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Option B. Lymphoma: Intraocular lymphoma is rare in children and typically presents differently, without the characteristic rosettes seen in retinoblastoma.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma: This malignancy affects the ocular surface and is not typically associated with intraocular masses or leukocoria. It also lacks the histological pattern of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retinoblastoma is identified by leukocoria, an intraocular mass in children, and the presence of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology, which are true rosettes specific to this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, and abdominal pain. He reports memory loss and reveals that he works at a battery recycling plant. On examination, a noticeable foot drop in both lower extremities is seen. Laboratory testing shows elevated blood lead levels. Which enzyme is affected in the given scenario? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase

 

The question clearly indicates that it is a case of lead poisoning (elevated blood levels and associated clinical features)

 

Lead inhibits heme synthesis through inhibition of multiple enzymes involved in heme synthesis pathway, of which main inhibited enzymes are:

 

  • ALAD (Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase)- Mnemonic ALAD sounds like lead
  • Coproporphyrinogen oxidase
  • Ferrochelatase

 

This leads to increased levels of multiple precursors of Heme production like:

 

  • Protoporphyrin
  • Coproporphyrin
  • δ-amino levulinic acid

 

 

Other options

 

Option B. Uroporphyrinogen III: Not directly inhibited by lead. Uroporphyrinogen III synthase is involved in the conversion of hydroxymethylbilane to uroporphyrinogen III.

 

Option C. Uroporphyrinogen I: Not directly involved in lead poisoning. Uroporphyrinogen I is a precursor in the heme synthesis pathway but not specifically inhibited by lead.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase: Not involved in the heme synthesis pathway. This enzyme is part of the metabolic pathway converting pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in cellular respiration.

 

Educational Objective

 

Lead poisoning primarily inhibits the enzyme Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) dehydratase (ALAD), leading to disruptions in the heme synthesis pathway and accumulation of heme precursors.

questions.text: Addison's disease can present with symptoms similar to which of the following disorders? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Depression

 

Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, is a condition where the adrenal glands do not produce sufficient steroid hormones, specifically cortisol and aldosterone. Symptoms of Addison's disease include fatigue, muscle weakness, weight loss, low blood pressure, and skin hyperpigmentation. These symptoms, especially fatigue, muscle weakness, and weight loss, can overlap with the symptoms of depression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized anxiety disorder primarily involves excessive, uncontrollable worry about everyday events. It is not usually seen in Addison’s disease.

 

Option C. Bipolar disorder is characterized by mood episodes, including mania (or hypomania) and depression. It may be seen in Addison’s disease, but it is rare.

 

Option D. Panic disorder is characterized by recurrent unexpected panic attacks, which are sudden periods of intense fear or discomfort. It is not usually seen in Addison’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Addison's disease is due to hypofunctioning of the adrenocortical system. It can mimic depression due to overlapping symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and low mood. It is essential to consider medical conditions that can present similarly to psychiatric disorders to ensure accurate diagnosis and treatment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 682.

questions.text: Identify the organ most likely lined by the type of epithelium seen in the provided histological section. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ureter

 

The histology slide shown displays transitional epithelium, also known as urothelium. Transitional epithelium is characterized by multiple layers of cells with a distinct upper layer composed of umbrella cells, which are often binucleated and exhibit a dome-shaped appearance. These umbrella cells allow the epithelium to stretch and accommodate varying volumes of fluid, a feature that is crucial for organs in the urinary system like the ureter, bladder, and renal pelvis. This epithelium type is specific to the urinary tract, allowing it to expand and contract without losing integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenum: The duodenum is lined with simple columnar epithelium with microvilli, designed for absorption and not seen in multilayered transitional cells.

 

Option B. Gall bladder: The gall bladder has a simple columnar epithelium without cilia or transitional characteristics. Its primary function is to concentrate and store bile, requiring an absorptive surface rather than a stretchable one.

 

Option C. Trachea: The trachea is lined with pseudostratified columnar ciliated epithelium containing goblet cells, designed to trap and move particles, which is distinct from the structure of transitional epithelium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transitional epithelium, marked by umbrella cells and multilayered structure, is primarily found in the urinary tract, including the ureter,  urinary bladder and upper part of urethra where it facilitates expansion and contraction.
